Award.AwardTitle: CNH-Ex: Investigating the Dynamic Intersections Among Economic Development, Urbanization, and Forest Degradation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate how economic and environmental changes affect the relationships among urban energy demands, urban and rural livelihoods, and the health of ecosystems that urban residents rely on for critical resources. The project will focus on issues associated with the complex ways in which human responses to changing demographic, economic, and environmental conditions lead to local-level decisions that can have significant impacts on the ways in which urban areas and the resource systems on which they depend function. The project will help develop new theoretical insights into what incentivizes human behavior regarding natural resource use under rapidly changing economic, demographic, and environmental contexts, and it will enhance methodological capabilities to identify changes in ecosystems in locales that traditionally have not been subject to ongoing monitoring. The project also will improve capabilities to forecast patterns of resource supply and demand related to changing socioeconomic and environmental conditions. The project has the potential to benefit society by informing policies that aim to combat environmental degradation and facilitate sustainable urban growth. The project will yield valuable data that will be made readily accessible through institutionally maintained archives, thereby facilitating future research, and it will provide special graduate student education and training opportunities. This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program.

Recent scientific research has identified poverty, environmental degradation, and extreme weather as key drivers of urbanization in Africa and in many other parts of the developing world. Although only 30 percent of the African population lived in urban centers in 2000, this percentage is projected to double by 2050, with the majority of growth occurring in small- to medium-sized cities. Given the heavy reliance on charcoal as an energy source in African cities, rapid urbanization likely will increase forest degradation. This project will investigate interactions among urban and rural livelihoods and the health of the Miombo woodland ecosystems. Miombo woodlands are the most extensive forested ecosystem in Africa, covering 2.7-million square-km throughout eight southern African countries. The researchers will investigate how local-level decisions regarding charcoal production and consumption in changing economic and environmental contexts influence rates of forest degradation in Mozambique's Miombo woodlands. They will examine the charcoal trade in Tete, a mid-sized but rapidly growing city, to analyze how simultaneous economic and environmental change impact the well-being of people and the landscapes in which they live. They will integrate socioeconomic analysis and ecosystem modeling to better understand forest degradation in poorer regions that are rapidly integrating into the global economy. The results of the socioeconomic analyses will enable the refinement of an ecosystem model that accounts for consumer and producer preferences in charcoal production systems and their impact on forest degradation rates. The model will be used to simulate charcoal-driven forest degradation under various social, economic, and environmental scenarios in order to identify patterns that could compromise the sustainable use of Miombo woodlands and the well-being of urban and rural residents. Although focusing on a specific case study in Mozambique, many facets of the analysis will be of value in understanding coupled natural and human system dynamics in other nations and ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study investigated how local-level decisions regarding charcoal production and consumption influence rates of forest degradation in African dry woodlands. Using Mozambique as a case study, this project integrates socio-economic analysis and ecosystem modeling to better understand forest degradation in poorer regions rapidly integrating into the global economy. The project lies at the intersection of human and physical geography, forestry, and ecology. Drawing on these different fields helps us better understand the interactions between socio-economic and environmental change.

US and Mozambican scholars collaborated in achieving the following goals: 1) develop new theories of human behavior regarding natural resource use; 2) enhance existing methodologies for measuring forest degradation by incorporating ground-based information on biophysical conditions, and information on local decision-making; and 3) improve the quality of forest degradation forecasts to identify future trends in natural resources use in rapidly urbanizing environments.

The research provides theoretical insights into what incentivizes charcoal production and use under rapidly changing economic, demographic, and environmental contexts. We find that forest degradation associated with charcoal production in the study area is largely independent of deforestation driven by agricultural expansion. Dry woodlands are progressively degraded by three distinct, sequential charcoal production waves. Producers quickly become less selective as preferred tree species for charcoal become scarce. However, even extremely selective charcoal production systems cause considerable modification to forest structure. Our research suggests that woodland ecosystems and carbon stocks in the case study area could reach critical environmental thresholds within 15 years. We also find that the environmental consequences of an expanding producer population are more serious than charcoal poverty traps.

The research has also expanded methodological capabilities to identify changes in ecosystems in locales that traditionally have not been subject to ongoing monitoring. Our work illustrates the feasibility of using estimates of urban charcoal consumption to establish a link between urban energy demands and forest degradation. We established a procedure for using high-resolution remote sensing images to map kiln locations to characterize the spatial extent and temporal dynamics of charcoal production. The integration of interview and survey data, biophysical measurements, and population projections into an ecosystem model, enabled us to generate plausible future scenarios of forest degradation.  By calibrating an ecosystem model to incorporate biomass extraction patterns associated with distinct scenarios of charcoal production, we have improved existing forecasting capabilities of forest regeneration dynamics and generated more reliable estimates of carbon stocks and fluxes in the region.

This work represents a significant improvement of the current understanding of forest degradation in tropical dry forests of southern Africa, and a first step towards developing charcoal-focused forest degradation monitoring systems. Research findings have been disseminated to communities of interest in the form of scholarly manuscripts, international and national conference presentations, invited talks, and a project website. The research funding from NSF has facilitated the development of a strong international collaboration that will continue to conduct research and publish findings in the future.

The project benefits society by informing policies that aim to combat environmental degradation, mitigate poverty, and facilitate sustainable urban growth. The project has yielded valuable primary socio-economic and biophysical data that has been made publicly available to the broader research community on a long-term basis via the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research?s (ICPSR) digital archive, thereby facilitating future research. The project has provided STEM education and training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at US and Mozambican universities. Improving the skills and abilities of Mozambican students to conduct STEM research enables them to better inform national policies and improve social, economic, and environmental conditions in the country. Over the course of the project, the PI and the co-PI have worked with two US graduate students, one US undergraduate intern as part of the National Socio-environmental Synthesis Center (SESYNC) mentorship program, one undergraduate research assistant, one Mozambican graduate student, and seven Mozambican undergraduate students, providing training and mentorship in conducting international research. The PI and several international colleagues also incorporated research findings into their university course curriculums, thereby presenting the research results to numerous students.
